item.title: The Krampus: Slideshow Talk with Costumes (early show)
item.dc:creator: Al Ridenour
item.description: The Krampus, the dark companion to St. Nicholas once known only in German-speaking Europe, is currently experiencing dubious fame as an AmericanÂ movie star. Learn the myths behind the myths, as Al Ridenour ofÂ Krampus Los AngelesÂ explores the authentic folklore and contemporary practice with slides, video, and appearances by a cavalcade of costumed associates. Wildly out of […]
item.content:encoded:
The Krampus, the dark companion to St. Nicholas once known only in German-speaking Europe, is currently experiencing dubious fame as an AmericanÂ movie star. Learn the myths behind the myths, as Al Ridenour ofÂ Krampus Los AngelesÂ explores the authentic folklore and contemporary practice with slides, video, and appearances by a cavalcade of costumed associates.

Wildly out of step with our modern, gentle Christmas, the Krampus is actually far from shocking when viewed against his historic backdrop. Tonight, weâ€ll learn about the creatureâ€s relationship to centuries-old witchcraft beliefs and explore the old, darker notion of the Christmas season as one offering access to the spirit world. In Germany and Austria, on these nights, ghost armies once rode the skies, witches gathered for their sabbaths, and magicians might transform themselves into werewolves. Even the Catholic saints could turn into monstrous apparitions â€” the hammer wielding â€œBloody Thomasâ€ of St. Thomas Night, theÂ Luz, threatening children with her sickle on St. Lucyâ€s, and the moss-faced crones who even today chase young people with switches on St. Barbaraâ€s Night. The Krampus and nearly a dozen of these monstrous relatives (including the towering goat-likeÂ HabergeiÃŸ) will be marshaled through the Goethe-Institut auditorium by Al Ridenour, co-producer, with Al Guerrero, of the Los Angeles Krampusfest, now in its third year. This 2015 Goethe-Institut presentation includes costumes and imagery not shown in 2014.

After the lecture there will be mulled wine (GlÃ¼hwein) and a chance to take photos with performers and socialize in the Goethe-Institut reception area.

$1 PARKING: FromÂ Wilshire turn south on Courtyard Place forÂ underground parkingÂ  (only $1 with validation).

The Krampus and nearly a dozen of these monstrous relatives (including the towering goat-likeÂ HabergeiÃŸ) will be marshaled through the Goethe-Institut auditorium by Al Ridenour, co-producer, with Al Guerrero, of the Los Angeles Krampusfest, now in its third year. item.title: Traditional Krampus Play and Krampus Films (early show)
item.dc:creator: Al Ridenour
item.description: While your fanboy friends rhapsodize about the ersatz Krampus of American movies and comic books, tonight youâ€™ll get a glimpse of the old devil in his oldest, purestÂ form â€“ the Krampus of the ancient alpine â€œNikolausspielâ€Â orÂ NICHOLAS PLAY,Â aÂ folk theater genre dating back to the 18thÂ century and resemblingÂ Englandâ€™s ChristmasÂ mummersâ€™ plays. The Nicholas Play is a primary origin […]
item.content:encoded:
While your fanboy friends rhapsodize about the ersatz Krampus of American movies and comic books, tonight youâ€ll get a glimpse of the old devil in his oldest, purestÂ form â€“ the Krampus of the ancient alpine â€œNikolausspielâ€Â orÂ NICHOLAS PLAY,Â aÂ folk theater genre dating back to the 18thÂ century and resemblingÂ Englandâ€s ChristmasÂ mummersâ€ plays. The Nicholas Play is a primary origin of the Krampus tradition, and for tonightâ€s presentation, weâ€ve translated scenes from surviving German scripts to give you a taste of how the Krampus was experienced in Alpine villages of centuries gone by.

Even in Austria, this is a rare experience, as the tradition has died out in all but a few towns and villages. This increasingly tenuous link to the past is now recognized by UNESCOâ€s on their World Heritage list as part ofÂ Austriaâ€s â€œIntangible Cultural Heritage.â€

While all this cultural import may sound too serious for fun, weâ€ve not forgotten our audience. Our Los Angeles production combines only the most attractive and amusing scenes involving the Krampus, Lucifer,Â butchered children, andÂ the inexorable power of Death, all represented in bouncy rhyme. Whether speaking of eternal salvation or the merciless tortures of Hell, the dialogue of theÂ NikolausspielÂ is inevitablyÂ delivered in cheery couplets worthy of Dr. Seuss.

Following the play, weâ€re presenting a program of specially curated FILMSÂ to give you a glimpse into the rough-and-tumble world of the Krampus as he existed in the early part of the 20thÂ century and today. In rare footage from the Austrian State Archives, youâ€ll see characters from the Nicholas Play you just watched bursting into homesÂ and taverns, Krampuses carrying off armfuls of children and engaging in pranks, property damage, attempted theft, and heavy drinking. Other shorts depict the most violent Krampus activity in the world, parades of child-Krampuses, and entertaining bouts of hysteria that attend the devilâ€s appearance.

Guests for our double bill are invited to come in themed wardrobe, period clothing, or holiday attire, festive orÂ grim. On hand will also be Bay Area artist KimricÂ Smytheâ€sÂ KRAMPUS-DRIVEN STEAMCAR.Â The event takes place amid the candles and stained glass of the historicÂ CHURCH OF THE ANGELS, an exquisite Gothic Revival edifice built in 1889.

item.title: LAVA’s Thanksgiving at Clifton’s Cafeteria
item.dc:creator: Richard Schave
item.description: Please join the Los Angeles Visionaries Association for a return of their traditional Thanksgiving gathering at Clifton’s Cafeteria. You are invited to join the LAVA community for a no-host Thanksgiving afternoon gathering in the newly re-opened Clifton’s Cafeteria. Have your holiday meal or enjoy dessert and coffee with your friends and extended LAVA family in […]
item.content:encoded:
Please join the Los Angeles Visionaries Association for a return of their traditional Thanksgiving gathering at Clifton’s Cafeteria.

You are invited to join the LAVA community for a no-host Thanksgiving afternoon gathering in the newly re-opened Clifton’s Cafeteria. Have your holiday meal or enjoy dessert and coffee with your friends and extended LAVA family in a private dining room. Space is limited, so please only reserve if you intend to attend. You can register for this free event by clicking the “buy tickets” link above. No “plus ones,” so tell your friends to sign up using their own accounts.
